name: The Spy and the Traitor: The Greatest Espionage Story of the Cold War

title: A thriller and shows how close we came to nuclear war with Russia
content: A fantastic read if you are into spy stories - and it's true. Given Putin's threat of nuclear attack, it's helpful to know that it nearly happened during the Reagan presidency. The double agent, Oleg Gordievsky knew that Andropov  believed that the US would strike first, and, like Putin, he was  looking for 'evidence' to back up his belief. Gordievsky's information was deemed so believable, that it influenced Reagan to calm the situation.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2022

title: Verified Purchase
content: I was very interested to read this account of the KGB Colonel who used his disenchantment of Communism and a Totalitarian regime to  effectively spy for the West. I have no use for someone who would betray their county for a better car or cash (Aldrich Ames, Harold James Nicholson) in hand but I do understand trying to bring about change for the country you love that you feel is on the wrong path. I really admire Oleg Gordievsky for the difficult choices he made. I was heartbroken for him that the KGB refused to release his wife and children for so long that their marriage didn’t survive. In a totalitarian state it’s sad that you can’t trust your own spouse not to turn you in. That type of regime turns brother against brother, children against parents and the family is the loser in the end. But the story was enthralling and especially the end.  I am passing this book along to my peeps.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2023

title: Verified Purchase
content: “The Spy And The Traitor” is the riveting true story of Oleg Gordievsky, a high level KGB operative, exfiltrated out of the Soviet Union in July 1985 after years of spying for the Brits. Ben McIntyre, the author,  writes with extraordinary detail, dividing the spy world between “good guys” and “ bad guys,” naming names (not just of spies) but of British politicians and notables complicit with the KGB. McIntyre’s lengthy Part III, the actual exfiltration of the spy to Finland, is mesmerizing holding the reader’s attention  as if shackled to page after page of the clever disguise and artifice.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2020

title: The most compelling, intriguing and unbelievable true story that I've ever read!
content: It's very hard to put into words how this story affected me. Other reviewers have done a very thorough job of outlining the story. I can only encourage you to read it, and then challenge you to be able to put it down! My only critique (not of the book, but the formatting) is if you're reading this on your Kindle, that during the climax of the story, it is interrupted by several pages of photographs that are spoilers, before you read the outcome! So, be warned to close your eyes and fast forward. I hope that someone such as Tom Hanks, Steven Spielberg, or one of the great directors that excels at bringing epic stories such as this to life will get to work on this excellent story. Thank you, Oleg Gordievsky,  for everything you've done for England and America in the name of democracy.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2018

title: Better than Fiction
content: Of the five Ben Macintyre true stories I've read, Spy and The Traitor is the best, and even the best fiction thriller cannot capture the realism this book does. If this book helps to keep the horrors of Socialism/Communism and the Soviet Union and Russia alive in the minds of those who were too young to know about it maybe that system will be less likely to ever re-emerge, although it would appear that Putin would like to have it all back. Deepest bows to MI6 and MI5 for their remarkable, dedicated work and continuing loyalty to Oleg Gordievsky, the KGB spy at the center of this who hated the evils of Communistic Russia and risked everything to help end it and was in fact pivotal in its demise. Don't miss this book. Note: Don't review the second set of photos/captions before finishing the book as they contain spoilers.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2023

title: Verified Purchase
content: I could not put this book down.  It is the true story of a rising star in the Russian KGB who became disenchanted with communism and methodically, planfully became a British spy who persevered, and survived, over decades.  He lived a double life and narrowly evaded detection and death numerous times.  The cloak and dagger machinations on both Russian and British sides are worthy of a John Le Carre or Ian Fleming novel.  The extraordinary courage of the hero is admirable, and insights into his thought processes are fascinating, as his deeply held principles guide him to make profound personal sacrifices for a greater ideal.  This true story gives us a fascinating glimpse into the world of espionage of which we are mostly unaware, but which can have enormous impact on our lives.  I highly recommend this book.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2020
